review.title: Discovering Underlying Plans Based on Distributed Representations of Actions
review.abstract: Plan recognition aims to discover target plans (i.e., sequences of actions) behind observed actions, with history plan libraries or domain models in hand. Previous approaches either discover plans by maximally "matching" observed actions to plan libraries, assuming target plans are from plan libraries, or infer plans by executing domain models to best explain the observed actions, assuming complete domain models are available. In real world applications, however, target plans are often not from plan libraries and complete domain models are often not available, since building complete sets of plans and complete domain models are often difficult or expensive. In this paper we view plan libraries as corpora and learn vector representations of actions using the corpora; we then discover target plans based on the vector representations. Our approach is capable of discovering underlying plans that are not from plan libraries, without requiring domain models provided. We empirically demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach by comparing its performance to traditional plan recognition approaches in three planning domains.

sections.heading: Conclusion and Discussion
sections.text: In this paper, we present a novel plan recognition approach DUP based on the vector representation of actions. First, we learn the vector representations of actions from plan libraries using the Skip-gram model, which has proven effective. Then, we discover unobserved actions with the vector representations by repeatedly scanning actions and optimizing the likelihood that potential plans will be detected. We also demonstrate empirically the effectiveness of our approach. While in this essay we focused on a unique detection task, human-in-the-loop planning in practice will consist of multiple iterations, whereby DUP recognizes the plan and proposes action alternatives; the human makes a selection and revises the plan. The goal is to provide a form of flexible plan completion tools, similar to the auto-completioners for search engine queries.
